newsitem.title: USA: NY precious metals called to open higher.
newsitem.headline: NY precious metals called to open higher.

text.p: COMEX and NYMEX precious metals futures were expected to open higher Wednesday after U.S. stocks and bonds sustained further losses Tuesday, but dealers remained cautious because of the threat of producer selling.
COMEX December gold was called up $1.00 to $1.50 from Tuesday's close of $330.80 an ounce after trading from $331.00 to $332.80.
In the bullion market, spot gold was quoted at $328.60/$329.10 early compared to the London morning fix of $328.60.
COMEX warehouse gold stocks jumped 3,137 ounces to 947,705 ounces in Tuesday's data, while COMEX silver stocks fell 2,473,145 ounces to 166,671,282 ounces.
Dealers are said to be keeping an eye on the U.S. retail sales and producer prices for any signs of inflation.
COMEX September silver was called up two to three cents from Tuesday's close of $4.425.
NYMEX October platinum was expected to open $2 higher from Tuesday's close of $435.00, with NYMEX September palladium called up the same from the previous close of $218.00.

Overnight, TOCOM platinum and palladium prices finished lower, continuing a selling spree that started with the settlement of a strike at South Africa's Impala Platinum Holdings (Implats) late Monday.
